I Status of Radio Today
Radio as a creative medium and as a national
interconnected system was '’killed" by television.
With its greater money-making potential, television
took over the national broadcasting scene and almost
totally absorbed the energies and attention of top
executives and creative people in the major broad¬
casting organizations.
As a result, radio was left without central
direction, and went the way the marketplace decreed,
which was to a virtually complete break-up of old
networking and to the emergence of independent local
stations as the dominant force in the medium. Local
radio has evolved into a small number of different
formats, which, with only a few exceptions, have become
standard all over the country.
By far the most common is the so-called "Top 40"
station, in which best-selling records (rock and roll
or country music) are played around the clock, inter¬
rupted occasionally by a minute or three or four minutes,
of news ripped from the AP or UPI wires and read at
a breakneck pace. Other standard formats include the
"all talk" station on which people call the* talkmaster*
and put their opinions on the air, and the "all news"
station (only a few of these) where the same news
headlines with variations are repeated over and
over again. In a few cities, classical music is
being supplied by FM stations, and in many cities,
"middle-of-the-road" music has proved popular on both
AM and FM outlets.
Educational radio has never been national, either
in interconnection or in programming or in coverage.
Of the over 300 educational stations, a great majority
are low power stations designed to serve colleges and
other institutions. Many of them perform useful
